ModalWindow Class Reference

#include <ModalWindow.h>

Inheritance diagram for ModalWindow:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

A modal window is a window that support a special mode where the user is constraint to react to this window before being able to operate with other parts of the Desktop.

Programmatically, the run stays in a special method of the modal window, runModally(), and the Glaziery main loop is called recursively. Thus, the application (or game) may use modal windows to display dialogs and continue working with the data entered by the user just after having called runModally().

See also:
runModally()

Definition at line 25 of file ModalWindow.h.

Member Function Documentation

void appendListener (  Listener *  listener  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a listener at the end of the listeners of this listenable object.

Appended listeners are called last.

Parameters:
listener The listener to be added.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any listenable object anymore. So you should not hold any references to them and you should not manually delete them.

void appendWidget (  Widget *  widget  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a component widget at the end of the widgets of this component.

Appended widgets are considered last.

Parameters:
widget The widget to be added.
Note:
Widgets may only be added to one component at a time.

After the call, the memory is owned by this object. You should not delete it, it will be done automatically.

void bringToFront (  bool  focus = true  )  [inherited]
 

Brings this window to the foreground, in front of all other windows.

The window automatically gets focus then.

Parameters:
focus Whether this window should initially get focus. Defaults to true.

void cancelEffects (   )  [inherited]
 

Cancels all effects currently running for this component.

This method is useful before added new effects.

void center (   )  [inherited]
 

Moves the component to be located in the center of its parent.

bool close (   ) 
 

Gracefully tries to close the window, removing it from the Glaziery system.

This method should be used for regular window closes with user interaction. First, all window listeners are notified using onClosing(). They may veto the window close. If noone does, they are again notified about the close having performed, using onClosed(). The window is then destroyed by adding it to the list of disposable components, which finally destroys it on next call of Desktop::draw().

Note:
The component is maybe added to the list of disposable components. Nevertheless, the memory is still available until the next call to Desktop::draw() (the next frame).

Use Desktop::removeWindow() to remove the window ungracefully, without user interaction and close notification.

Returns:
Whether the close was performed. Any veto results in false.
See also:
Listener::onClosing()

Listener::onClosed()

Reimplemented from Window.

Menu* createMenu (   )  [inherited]
 

Creates a menu for this window and sets it as the window's menu.

If a menu already exists, the old one is automatically destroyed.

Returns:
The new menu for this window.
See also:
getMenu()

void deleteChild (  Component *  child  )  [protected, inherited]
 

Destroys a component, if it is a child of this component.

If not (which is illegal), an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
child The child to be destroyed.

virtual void destroy (   )  [virtual]
 

Removes the component from the Glaziery system to destroy it.

First performs operations before the component is destroyed, then adds it to the Desktop's list of disposables.

Note:
The component is added to the list of disposable components. Nevertheless, the memory is still available until the next call to Desktop::draw() (the next frame).

This is an ungraceful removal, without user interaction and close notifications, but with destroy noficiation. E.g. for windows, use Window::close() to close normally.

Reimplemented from Window.

virtual void draw (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Draws the component to the display surface.

This is usually achieved by delegating to the current skin.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Note:
The caller is responsible for not calling this method if the component is invisible.
See also:
Desktop::getSkin()

Reimplemented from Component.

virtual void drawContent (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Draws the content of the component to the display surface.

This is usually achieved by delegating to the current skin.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Note:
The implementation must clear the context before rendering, if it does not render to the entire context.

This method is called when the cache is invalid only. See invalidate() and the CachableComponent's class comment for details.

See also:
Desktop::getSkin()

Vector getAbsolutePosition (   )  [inherited]

unsigned char getAlpha (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the alpha blending value, defining the grade of transparency of this component.

Checks whether the component has focus and uses the appropriate alpha value. An alpha value of 0 represents complete transparency (i.e. the component is invisible), and 255 represents complete opaqueness.

Returns:
The alpha value.

virtual Vector getChildrenOrigin (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns the origin of children of this component.

Typically it is the absolute position of this component. However, components with scrolling child views (e.g. the ScrollingArea), have a different origin.

Returns:
The children origin.

Reimplemented in ScrollingArea.

ClientArea* getClientArea (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the client area of the window.

The client area is the rectangular region that remains when leaving out the frame area. The client area is a separate component and must be set into the window.

Returns:
The client area.

const ArrayList<ComponentEffect>& getEffects (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the component effects currently running for this component.

Returns:
The component effects.

virtual EventTarget* getEventTargetAt (  Vector  position  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns the event target at a given position that is setup to receive pointer events.

For popup components, this is always true, for windows, this is true if and only if the pointer event mode is active or inactive, but bypassing windows are treated as not existing (transparent for events), and for widgets, this depends on the widget's hit test (isHitAt()).

This is a deep search: The desktop delegates to the found window or popup component, which delegates to the client area and so on.

Parameters:
position The position relative to the event target's origin. For components, this is their absolute position, for widgets, this is the absolute position of their component.
Returns:
The event receiving event target at the position or NULL, if there is no target.

Reimplemented from Component.

Returns the alpha blending value, defining the grade of transparency of this component, if it has focus (is active).

An alpha value of 0 represents complete transparency (i.e. the component is invisible), and 255 represents complete opaqueness.

Returns:
The alpha value.

void* getModel (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Returns:
The application (or game) defined data.

Returns the alpha blending value, defining the grade of transparency of this component, if it has no focus (is inactive).

SkinData* getSkinData (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Returns:
The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

Reimplemented from Component.

void hideDeferred (   )  [inherited]
 

Defers the hide operation, executing it by the main thread.

Note:
Glaziery is not thread-safe in the most part of it. All glaziery objects (including windows, fields, etc.) may not be accessed by any other thread than the main thread. Concurrent threads created using the platform adapter's createThread method must therefore place operations on Glaziery objects into a deferral queue. Use this method from any concurrent thread.
See also:
Desktop::deferOperation()

)  [inherited]

Parameters:

listener The listener to be added.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any listenable object anymore. So you should not hold any references to them and you should not manually delete them.

void maximize (   )  [inherited]
 

Maximizes the window to full desktop size.

The original position and size are memorized and will be restored when calling restore(). This method does the following: First, the position and size of the window is set to full desktop. Then, the maximize flag is set, so calling isMaximized() will then return true. Finally, all listeners' onMoved(), onResized(), and onMaximized() methods are called (in that order).

See also:
restore()

isMaximized()

Component::Listener::onMoved()

Component::Listener::onResized()

Component::Listener::onMaximized()

)  [protected, virtual, inherited]

virtual long onHold (  Vector  position,
long  holdTime
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that, after the event target is pressed down (usually using the left mouse button), the pointer is not moved, but the button has not yet been released.

onHold() is called in the time between onPress() and onRelease(). Glaziery provides the time between the last call of onHold() and this one. It expects that the onHold implementation issues in its return value the hold time not consumed. If 0 is returned, all the time has been consumed and the holdTime reflects only the time between two consecutive onHold() calls each time. If a positive value is returned, this value is added to the next holdTime value. This helps to implement operations that have to be performed after some time has elapsed, while not losing remaining milli seconds. The following code snippet illustrates this operation: 


 long MyClass::onHold(Vector position, long holdTime)
 {
 	while (holdTime >= 100)
 	{
 		performSomeOperation();
 		holdTime -= 100;
 	}
 	return holdTime;
 }
Parameters:
position The current position of the pointer relative to the upper-left corner of the event target's origin. For components, this is their absolute position, for widgets, this is the absolute position of their component.
holdTime The hold time between the last call of onHold() and this one, plus the hold time not consumed in the last call of onHold(). The time's unit is milli seconds.
Returns:
The hold time this method has not consumed in milli seconds.
See also:
onPress()

onRelease()

Reimplemented in ScrollingArea, and ScrollingField.

virtual bool onHotKey (  char  character,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that a hot key has been pressed on the component.

Hot keys represent special characters e.g. to easily access fields (indicated by underlined characters).

character The hot key character pressed.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
Returns:
Whether the event target has consumed the event. If false, the event is first passed to the desktop and then to the input manager to increase event quantities.

Reimplemented from EventTarget.

option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

Whether the event target has consumed the event. If false, the event is first passed to the desktop and then to the input manager to increase event quantities.

Reimplemented from EventTarget.

Reimplemented in ScrollingArea, ListField::RowsField, RadioBox, Selector, TextField, and TreeField.

void prependListener (  Listener *  listener  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a listener at the beginning of the listeners of this listenable object.

Prepended listeners are called first.

Parameters:
listener The listener to be added.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any listenable object anymore. So you should not hold any references to them and you should not manually delete them.

void prependWidget (  Widget *  widget  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a component widget at the beginning of the widgets of this component.

Prepended widgets are considered first.

Parameters:
widget The widget to be added.
Note:
Widgets may only be added to one component at a time.

After the call, the memory is owned by this object. You should not delete it, it will be done automatically.

virtual void releaseCache (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Invalidates and releases this component's internal caches (e.g.

drawing caches). This method should be when it is unlikely that the cache will be needed in the near future, to release system resources (e.g. when the component gets invisible).

Reimplemented from CachableComponent.

void removeListener (  Listener *  listener  )  [inherited]
 

Removes a listener from the list of listeners and then deletes it, if it is no longer used.

Parameters:
listener The listener to be removed and deleted.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any listenable object anymore. So you should not hold any references to them.

void removeMenu (   )  [inherited]
 

Removes the menu of this window, if it exists.

The menu object is automatically destroyed.

void removeWidget (  Widget *  widget  )  [inherited]
 

Removes a widget from the list of component widgets and then deletes it.

Parameters:
widget The widget to be removed and deleted.

bool resize (  Vector  size  )  [inherited]
 

Resizes the component.

This calls the listeners' onResized() method.

Parameters:
size The new size.
Returns:
Whether the component was actually resized.
Note:
Calling this method on fields or field areas relayouts the fields area, if automatic layouting is enabled, so consider turning it off while doing major changes to the fields of such fields area.

void resizeComponent (  Component *  relatedComponent,
Vector  size
)  [protected, inherited]
 

Resizes a related component (child, parent, ...).

No veto is possible, and the parent is not notified.

Parameters:
relatedComponent The related component to be resized.
size The new size.
Note:
Use this method only from within components that have to move related components. This method delegates to the moveInternal() method.
See also:
resize()

resizeInternal()

virtual bool resizeInternal (  Vector  size,
bool  notifyParent
)  [protected, virtual, inherited]
 

Resizes the component and handles listeners.

This method is called internally by the resize overload, and by parents resizing a child.

Note:
If the window is currently maximized, then this method has no immediate effect. However, calling restore() any later will restore the window with the new size.
Parameters:
size The new size.
notifyParent false, if the method has been called from the parent (e.g. onChildMoved() or onChildResized()). In this case, the child event handlers are not called again, to prevent an endless recursion or other inappropriate behavior.
Returns:
Whether the component was actually resized.
See also:
resize()

onChildMoved()

onChildResized()

Reimplemented from Component.

bool resizeToMaximum (   )  [inherited]
 

Resizes the component to the maximum size.

Returns:
Whether the component was actually resized.
Note:
Calling this method on fields or field areas relayouts the fields area, if automatic layouting is enabled, so consider turning it off while doing major changes to the fields of such fields area.

bool resizeToMinimum (   )  [inherited]
 

Resizes the component to the minimum size.

Returns:
Whether the component was actually resized.
Note:
Calling this method on fields or field areas relayouts the fields area, if automatic layouting is enabled, so consider turning it off while doing major changes to the fields of such fields area.

void restore (   )  [inherited]
 

Restores the window to the position and size before the last call to maximize(), except the moveTo() and/or resize() methods have been called after maximize().

In that case, the new position and/or size are restored. This method does the following: First, the position and size of the window are restored. Then, the maximize flag is reset, so calling isMaximized() will then return false. Finally, all listeners' onMoved(), onResized(), and onRestored() methods are called (in that order).

See also:
maximize()

moveTo()

resize()

isMaximized()

Component::Listener::onMoved()

Component::Listener::onResized()

Component::Listener::onRestored()

void runModally (   ) 
 

Runs Glaziery with the window in modal mode.

It behaves similarly to the desktop's run() method, but events are only passed to this window, which is brought to front first. The method does not return before a modal button has been pressed.

Warning:
This method causes a recursion in the event handling loop. Your effected classes should be able to handle respective reentrance and you should not cause an endless recursion.
See also:
Desktop::run()

Button

Button::isModal()

void sendToBack (   )  [inherited]
 

Sends this window to the background, behind all other windows.

If any other window exists, the window automatically loses focus.

void setActive (  bool  active  )  [inherited]
 

Sets whether the consumes and executes events, e.g.

by changing properties and/or notifying listeners. If set to false, events "fall through" this window to the next one below, resp. finally to the Desktop.

Parameters:
active Whether the consumes and executes events.

void setAutoShowing (  bool  autoShowing  ) 
 

Sets whether to automatically show the (maybe initially hidden) modal window when running into the modal loop (runModally, e.g.

Dialog::showDialog). Defaults to true.

Parameters:
autoShowing Whether to automatically show the window.

void setCaching (  bool  caching  )  [inherited]
 

Sets whether to cache the content of this component.

Defaults to true.

Warning:
Disabling the caching also results in graphical errors, because there is no image to create alpha blending effects on.
Parameters:
caching Whether to cache the content of this component.

void setCancelClosing (  bool  cancelClosing  )  [inherited]
 

Sets whether cancel events close the window.

Defaults to true. Has effect only when closable is set, too.

Parameters:
cancelClosing Whether cancel events close the window.

void setClientArea (  ClientArea *  clientArea  )  [inherited]
 

Sets the client area of the window.

The client area is the rectangular region that remains when leaving out the frame area. The client area is a separate component and must be set into the window.

Parameters:
clientArea The new client area. Any previous client area is automatically deleted.
Note:
After the call, the memory is owned by this object. You should not delete it, it will be done automatically.

void setClosable (  bool  closable  )  [inherited]
 

Sets whether the user can close the window using a special close widget.

The actual UI is defined by the skin.

Parameters:
closable Whether the user can close the window.

void setComponentMaximumSize (  Component *  component,
Vector  maximumSize,
bool  notifyParent
)  [protected, inherited]
 

Sets the maximum size of a component.

Resize operation are limited by this value. If the current size is bigger than the maximum size, the component is resized automatically.

Parameters:
component The component to set the maximum size of.
maximumSize The maximum size of the component.
notifyParent false, if the method has been called from the parent (e.g. onChildMoved() or onChildResized()). In this case, the child event handlers are not called again, to prevent an endless recursion or other inappropriate behavior.

void setComponentMinimumSize (  Component *  component,
Vector  minimumSize,
bool  notifyParent
)  [protected, inherited]
 

Sets the minimum size of a component.

Resize operation are limited by this value. If the current size is smaller than the maximum size, the component is resized automatically.

Parameters:
component The component to set the minimum size of.
minimumSize The minimum size of the component.
notifyParent false, if the method has been called from the parent (e.g. onChildMoved() or onChildResized()). In this case, the child event handlers are not called again, to prevent an endless recursion or other inappropriate behavior.

void setComponentParent (  Component *  child  )  [protected, inherited]
 

Sets the parent of a related child component when adding the child to this component.

You cannot change a parent once it has been set, except if you unset the parent first, which is not recommended for regular cases.

Parameters:
child The child to set the parent to this component.
Note:
Do not use this method in application (or game) code. Use this method in the parent component when implementing a method that adds a child (e.g. appendField in FieldsArea).
See also:
unsetComponentParent()

getParent()

void setDisposed (   )  [protected, inherited]
 

Sets that the component is about to be destroyed.

Usually, don't call this method directly. Use destroy() instead, which automatically deletes the object during the next frame.

eventConsuming Whether this window is event consuming.

An alpha value of 0 represents complete transparency (i.e. the component is invisible), and 255 represents complete opaqueness.

void setModel (  void *  model,
void(*  modelDestructor)(void *model) = NULL
)  [inherited]
 

Sets the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Parameters:
model The application (or game) defined data.
modelDestructor An optional static method that is called, whenever the glaziery object is destroyed or when a new model is set. Specify this function only, if the model must be destroyed by this glaziery object, i.e. the object "owns" the model. If the model is a glaziery object itself, you may use the GlazieryObject::destructor() function.
See also:
destructor()

Sets whether the user can move the window e.g.

dragging the title bar. The actual UI is defined by the skin.

Parameters:
movable Whether the user can move the window.

virtual void setSkinData (  SkinData *  skinData  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Sets the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Parameters:
skinData The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

Any previously set skin data is automatically destroyed.

Reimplemented from GlazieryObject.

void setTitleDeferred (  const String &  title  )  [inherited]
 

Defers the setTitle operation, executing it by the main thread.

Note:
Glaziery is not thread-safe in the most part of it. All glaziery objects (including windows, fields, etc.) may not be accessed by any other thread than the main thread. Concurrent threads created using the platform adapter's createThread method must therefore place operations on Glaziery objects into a deferral queue. Use this method from any concurrent thread.
Parameters:
title The new window title.
See also:
Desktop::addDeferredObject()

Desktop::executeDeferrals()

EventTarget::executeDeferrals()

void setTooltip (  const String &  tooltip  )  [inherited]
 

Sets the tooltip, a text that appears in a popup when the pointer is hovered over the event target.

Parameters:
tooltip The tooltip.

void setVisibleDeferred (  bool  visible  )  [inherited]
 

Defers the setVisible operation, executing it by the main thread.

Note:
Glaziery is not thread-safe in the most part of it. All glaziery objects (including windows, fields, etc.) may not be accessed by any other thread than the main thread. Concurrent threads created using the platform adapter's createThread method must therefore place operations on Glaziery objects into a deferral queue. Use this method from any concurrent thread.

This is a convenience method, it delegates to showDeferred() or hideDeferred().

Parameters:
visible The new visibility.
See also:
Desktop::deferOperation()

showDeferred()

void tutorialClick (  PointerEffect::ButtonEffect  buttonEffect = PointerEffect::BUTTONEFFECT_LEFTCLICK,
bool  option1 = false,
bool  option2 = false,
long  time = -1
)  [inherited]
 

For tutorials: Creates a pointer effect that moves the pointer to this component and clicks the component, and waits until the effect has ended.

Parameters:
buttonEffect The button effect (see PointerEffect::ButtonEffect) to be added (clicking, double-clicking, right-clicking the component). Only BUTTONEFFECT_LEFTCLICK, BUTTONEFFECT_DOUBLECLICK, and BUTTONEFFECT_RIGHTCLICK is allowed. To drag this component, use tutorialDragDropTo. Defaults to BUTTONEFFECT_LEFTCLICK;
option1 Whether option1 (e.g. Shift) is held during the button effect. Defaults to false.
option2 Whether option2 (e.g. Ctrl) is held during the button effect. Defaults to false.
time The time in milli seconds for the effect, or leave empty for a default.
Returns:
The newly created tutorial effect.
Note:
Use this method in Tutorial::run() implementations only.
See also:
Tutorial

void tutorialDragDropTo (  Vector  position,
bool  option1 = false,
bool  option2 = false,
long  time = -1
)  [inherited]
 

For tutorials: Creates a pointer effect that drags the component to another location and drops there, and waits until the effect has ended.

Parameters:
position The absolute position to drag-drop to.
option1 Whether option1 (e.g. Shift) is held during the button effect. Defaults to false.
option2 Whether option2 (e.g. Ctrl) is held during the button effect. Defaults to false.
time The time in milli seconds for the effect, or leave empty for a default.
Returns:
The newly created tutorial effect.
Note:
Use this method in Tutorial::run() implementations only.
See also:
Tutorial

void tutorialMoveTo (  long  time = -1  )  [inherited]
 

For tutorials: Creates a pointer effect that moves the pointer to this component and waits until the effect has ended.

Parameters:
time The time in milli seconds for the effect, or leave empty for a default.
Returns:
The newly created tutorial effect.
Note:
Use this method in Tutorial::run() implementations only.
See also:
Tutorial

void unfocus (   )  [inherited]
 

If this window currently has focus, passes the focus to the top-most visible window, that does not match this window.

Note:
The window is automatically unfocused, when it is destroyed.
See also:
destroy()

void unsetComponentParent (  Component *  child  )  [protected, inherited]
 

Unsets the parent of a related child component in the rare cases of removing the child from this component again.

Parameters:
child The child to unset the parent of.
Note:
Do not use this method in application (or game) code. Use this method in the parent component when implementing a method that removes a child (e.g. PopupWindow).
See also:
setComponentParent()

getParent()

bool autoShowing [protected]
 

Whether to automatically show the (maybe initially hidden) modal window when running into the modal loop (runModally, e.g.

Dialog::showDialog). Defaults to true. Use this property to delay showing the window until some event.
